>=
 I support the idea of having assertions as a separate library which is

ecoupled from the testing framework (the same way as Hamcrest,

t and probably others). The testing framework would then focus

>
> There is wide variablity in how assertions can =
be done (especially in

 about what an assert

nds of asserts as

>
> There is less variabl=
ity in testing frameworks' execution model, but
> those differences are oft=
en at a more fundamental level (e.g. test

and others hold strong opinions about them.

e to mix and match the frameworks and

en using multiple assertion libraries

>
> > - The fac=

and a mutable builder for the test structure, and then later an

le reference for the test structure, is exasperating.

 reflectively-discovered constructors for extensibility

wardness.

 all tests

d be at most
> > optional in a world in which tests are often run by daemon=
s many more
> times
> > a day than by humans.
>
> I've noticed those as wel=
l. I've already addressed each of those in Jumi:
>
> - A testing framework =
must assign a unique immutable TestId for each
> test in a test class, whic=
h is then used to send events of when the test
> was started, finished, fai=
led etc. The TestId implies a tree structure
> of tests (to be used in test=
 result reports). Everything is expressed as
> immutable events (Jumi relie=
s heavily on Event Sourcing). See details at
> http://jumi.fi/api/jumi-api/=
fi/jumi/api/drivers/SuiteNotifier.html
>
> - The fi.jumi.api.drivers.Driver=
 which corresponds
> org.junit.runner.Runner requires a zero-argument const=
ructor. The test
> class et al is passed as method argument to
> http://jum=
i.fi/api/jumi-api/fi/jumi/api/drivers/Driver.html#findTests
>
> - Jumi star=
ts executing tests as soon as possible, at both the suite and
> test class =
levels. At suite level, test class execution starts
> asynchronously before=
 all test classes are discovered (i.e. before Jumi
> has finished traversin=
g the directories containing test classes). At
> test class level, more tes=
ts can be found during test execution (for
> example Specsy requires this) =
and the new test executions can be started
> asynchronously in parallel (de=
pending on the testing framework and
> whether the user has disabled parall=
elism for that test class or the
> whole suite).
>
>
> > - There are as man=
y perfect models of test status possibilities as there
> > are developers. =
Passed/Failed? Passed/Failed/Skipped?
> > Passed/Failed/Ignored, etc. The c=
urrent design bakes one required system
> > pretty deep into the internals,=
 unnecessarily.
>
> That's been on my mind for a long time, but I haven't y=
et figured out a
> good way to support all the variations, so I'm deferring=
 the decision. I
> would love to hear your ideas.
>
> A very flexible way w=
ould be to allow tagging tests with arbitrary
> keywords, but then the prob=
lem will be that how each of those keywords
> should affect the user interf=
ace. There would have to be at least some
> keywords with specific meaning,=
 which brings us back to the original
> question of which states to support=
.
>
> To get started we could list all the variations in use today and the =
use
> cases for using each of them (e.g. it's an acceptance tests for a
> f=
eature which has not yet been implemented). I'm hoping there to be 5 or
> l=
ess different reasons that are served by test statuses.
>
>
> > Now, should=
 the framework to which I'd contribute time to fix these

lled JUnit 5, or something entirely different? That's

 fish, with some interesting options to consider. Looks

 least 9 months to consider them at length.

 to a baby. I suppose the names of quite many

or that long. :)

 On the other

gy can get
